heading: 2.2.2 Functions stop working
text: Strange behavior functions previously worked often caused function conflicts. can happen two packages loaded function names. indicate proper package, namespace . Conflicts commonly occur select filter map. intend tidyverse ones use:dplyr::select, dplyr::filter purrr::map.culprits:dplyr::summarise() vcdExtra::summarise()ggmosaic::mosaic() vcd::mosaic()leaflet::addLegend() xts::addLegend()dplyr::select MASS::select

heading: 2.3.1 knitr
text: Upon creating new R markdown file, always notice section like :chunk options refer first line can add following options:warning=FALSE - Suppress warningsmessage=FALSE – Suppress messages, especially useful loading packagescache=TRUE – changed chunks evaluated, careful though since changes dependencies detected.

heading: 2.3.2 Sizing figures
text: Always use chunk options size figures. can set default size YAML beginning .Rmd file :Another method click gear ⚙️ next Knit button, Output Options…, finally Figures tab.needed override one defaults particular chunks:{r, fig.width=4, fig.height=2}Figure related chunk options include fig.width, fig.height, fig.asp, fig.align; many .

text:
Insert R chunk
- option-command-(Mac) - ctrl+alt+(Windows)Insert %>% (“pipe”)
- shift-command-M (Mac) - ctrl+shift+M (Windows)Comment/Uncomment lines
- shift-command-C (Mac) - ctrl-shift+C (Windows)Knit Document

heading: 3 Learning ggplot2
text: page working progress :)

heading: 3.1 Getting Started
text: Hopefully, already experiences plotting basic R graphics. Chapter, briefly introduced one powerful plotting packages R: ggplot2 ’s basic grammar functions.Unlike graphics packages, one remarkable advantages ggplot2 underlying grammar enables compose graphs combining different components. can easily create novel graphics adding ggplot2 functions meet needs based data.definition grammar graphics, important features data mapping layers ’s getting started.
code:
library(ggplot2)
library(datasets)

# Using 'iris' in 'datasets' library as data
ggplot(data = datasets::iris) +  #Data part
  geom_point(aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width))  #Mapping part
ggplot(data = datasets::iris) +  #Data part
  geom_point(aes(Petal.Length, Petal.Width)) +  #layer 1 with mapping 
  geom_point(aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width), color='red')  #layer 2 with a different mapping

heading: 3.2.1 Geometric object, Statistical transformation and Position adjustment
text: layersGeometric object, Statistical transformation Position adjustment components can customized layer.Geometric objects geoms control type plot create. geom can display certain aesthetics visual attributes geom. example, point geom position, color, shape, size aesthetics. first decide kind plot better explains data choosing geoms use help function check aesthetics can modified achieve desired effects.statistical transformation stat transforms data, generally summarizing information. Position adjustment applied need adjust position elements plot dense data, otherwise data points might obscure one another.

heading: 3.2.2 Scale
text: scaleA scale controls data mapped aesthetic attributes, usually one scale every aesthetic property employed layer.
code:
ggplot(data = datasets::iris) + 
  geom_histogram(mapping=aes(x=Petal.Length, fill=Species), stat = 'bin',position = 'stack')+
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0, 10)) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 50))

heading: 3.2.3 Coordinate system
text: coordinate system coord maps position objects onto plane plot, controls axes grid lines drawn. One ggplot can one coord

heading: 3.2.4 Faceting
text: Faceting can used split data subsets entire dataset.

heading: 3.2.5 Labels
text: Labels include titles, labels x,y axis annotates. Good graphics also need give clear information using labels tell readers’ background knowledge data.
code:
ggplot(data = datasets::iris) + 
  geom_histogram(mapping=aes(x=Petal.Length, fill=Species), stat = 'bin',position = 'stack')+
  ggtitle('Stacked Histogram on Petal Length of Different Species') +
  xlab('Length of Petal')

heading: 3.3 ggplot2 Resources
text: implementations examples, one easiest way referring ggplot2 Cheatsheets provided R. Follow steps shown can find cheat-sheets RStudio.ggplot2_cheatsheets1ggplot2_cheatsheets2If seeking detailed explanations examples real datasets, useful links :ggplot2: Elegant Graphics

heading: 4 Unidimensional Continuous Variables
text: chapter, demonstrate types graphs using ggplot2.

heading: 4.1.1 Basics and implications
text:
start easy example.
example, used geom_histogram create histogram variable x. can see quick make need much pre-processing. Moreover, Histograms show data’s empirical distribution within set intervals suggest using one first steps understand data.Note: shown , ggplot expects dataframe, make sure throw vector ggplot.
code:
library(ggplot2)
library(gridExtra)

#Example data
x <- c(50, 51, 53, 55, 56, 60, 65, 65, 68)
#Stored as a dataframe
df <- data.frame(x)

ggplot(df, aes(x)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "grey", fill = "lightBlue", binwidth = 5, center = 52.5) +
  ggtitle("ggplot2 histogram of x")

heading: 4.1.2 Types of Histograms
text: y-scale histograms can represented variety ways express different results:Frequency count: y = number values fall binRelative frequency: y = number values fall bin / total number valuesCumulative frequency: y = total number values <= (<) right boundary binDensity: y = relative frequency / binwidth

heading: 4.1.3.1 Bin boundaries
text: mindful boundaries bins whether point fall left right bin boundary. can use parameter closed control intervals.
code:
p1 <- ggplot(df, aes(x)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue", binwidth = 5, center = 52.5, closed="left")  +
  ggtitle("Left Closed graph")

p2 <- ggplot(df, aes(x)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue", binwidth = 5, center = 52.5, closed="right")  +
  ggtitle("Right Closed graph")

grid.arrange(p1, p2, ncol = 2)

heading: 4.1.3.2 Bin numbers
text:
start passing parameters geom_histogram notice pop-saying default number bins 30.
see graph ideal gaps. two ways modify number bins: specify width explicitly binwidth provide desired number bins bins. Consider following modifications:Note: gold standard number bins, try different numbers generate best results.
code:
library(Sleuth3)
finches <- Sleuth3::case0201

#Default / Only adding some styles to make graph consistent
ggplot(finches, aes(x = Depth)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue") +
  ggtitle("Default with pop-up about bin number")
# using binwidth
p3 <- ggplot(finches, aes(x = Depth)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue",binwidth = 0.5, boundary = 6) +
  ggtitle("Changed binwidth value")

# using bins
p4 <- ggplot(finches, aes(x = Depth)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue",bins = 15, boundary = 6) +
  ggtitle("Changed bin value")

# format plot layout
grid.arrange(p3, p4, ncol = 2)

heading: 4.1.3.3 Bin alignment
text: Consider comparisonNotice boundary bins start axis difference code removal boundry. control position bins, can use either parameter center boundary. can use boundary specify endpoint bin center specify center bin ggplot2 able calculate place rest bins. (Also, notice boundary changed, number bins got smaller one. default bins centered go /range data.) example, specify boundary 6. can see first bin starts 6 position bins calculated based binwidth 0.5.
code:
p5 <- ggplot(finches, aes(x = Depth)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue",binwidth = 0.5) +
  ggtitle("Without alignment")

p6 <- ggplot(finches, aes(x = Depth)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue",bins = 15, boundary = 6) +
  ggtitle("With alignment")

grid.arrange(p5, p6, ncol = 2)

heading: 4.1.4 Interactive histograms with ggvis
text: ggvis package currently development, certain things well, adjusting parameters histogram interactively coding. interested, refer https://ggvis.rstudio.com/ggvis-basics.html.
